Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this workshop is to further methodological advances in simulation optimization for the setting in which evaluation of the objective function to be optimized is computationally expensive. The major complicating factors in simulation optimization are nonlinearities (and non-convexity) in the objective function and high dimensionality (e.g., from stochastic models or from discretizing nonlinear dynamics). A further key feature that makes simulation optimization more difficult than ordinary optimization is that the computational burden must be allocated between both the search and the evaluation, i.e., there is a basic tradeoff between exploring the search space and obtaining a better estimate of the performance (objective function) at the current candidate solutions.

Simulation is used throughout the US industry, frequently cited as the most widely used operations research technique, so if successful, this workshop will lead to advances in simulation optimization methodologies and techniques that would provide a competitive advantage to those companies that can integrate them in their long-term strategic and tactical planning, as well as in their more immediate execution and daily operations. Applications are numerous, from improved efficiencies in manufacturing operations, supply chain management, and telecommunications and transportation networks/systems (air, rail, road) to innovations in financial engineering products, pricing, and hedging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increasingly, computer simulation is the only way to model the large-scale, complex systems that underly most of the critical problems facing science, engineering and society, ranging from the creation of custom medicines via synthetic biology to the security of cyberinfrastructure to disaster relief. And in many of these contexts, the goal is optimization: Maximizing the efficacy of the therapy without becoming toxic; minimizing the chance of security breech without compromising access; and maximizing lives preserved within a critical time window, respectively. Whenever complex problems include uncertainty and risk, involve many interacting agents, and require solutions based on a high-fidelity representation of the world, the
use of simulation will be pervasive.


The purpose of this workshop was to identify and facilitate research that will lead to significant leaps forward in our ability to formulate, solve and interpret simulation optimization problems. Computer simulation is a broad term; the focus of this workshop was on stochastic simulations—simulations that mimic uncertainty and risk by generating random outcomes—and black-box simulations—computer models that must be optimized based solely on evaluating particular solutions and without knowledge of structural properties like convexity. Such problems are hard: The models are large-scale, taking from seconds to days to produce output. When random outcomes are incorporated, objectives can only be estimated and never known for sure. And the number of controllable design or decision variables may range from tens to thousands. Within this context, working groups identified essential research topics whose solution would remove the barriers that currently limit simulation optimization to small or highly-structured problems, or to being solved using commercial
software that provides no rigorous guarantees.
